examples.title: Change of Variables Formula
examples.statement: State and illustrate the change of variables formula for multiple integrals.

steps.title: Statement
steps.content:
If $T: E \to \mathbb{R}^n$ is a $C^1$ diffeomorphism and $f$ is integrable on $T(E)$, then:

$\int_{T(E)} f(y) \, dy = \int_E f(T(x)) |\det T'(x)| \, dx$

steps.title: Example: Polar coordinates
steps.content:
$T(r, \theta) = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta)$

$T'(r, \theta) = \begin{pmatrix} \cos\theta & -r\sin\theta \\ \sin\theta & r\cos\theta \end{pmatrix}$

$|\det T'| = r$

steps.title: Application
steps.content:
To integrate $f(x, y)$ over a disk of radius $R$:

$\iint_{x^2+y^2 \leq R^2} f(x, y) \, dx\, dy = \int_0^{2\pi} \int_0^R f(r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta) \cdot r \, dr \, d\theta$

solution.conclusion: The Jacobian determinant accounts for how $T$ stretches/shrinks volume elements.

exercises.statement: Use the change of variables formula to compute $\int_0^{\infty} e^{-x^2} \, dx$.

steps.title: Square the integral
steps.content:
Let $I = \int_0^{\infty} e^{-x^2} \, dx$.

$I^2 = \int_0^{\infty} e^{-x^2} \, dx \cdot \int_0^{\infty} e^{-y^2} \, dy = \int_0^{\infty}\int_0^{\infty} e^{-(x^2+y^2)} \, dx \, dy$

steps.title: Convert to polar
steps.content: $I^2 = \int_0^{\pi/2} \int_0^{\infty} e^{-r^2} \cdot r \, dr \, d\theta$

steps.title: Compute radial integral
steps.content: $\int_0^{\infty} r e^{-r^2} \, dr = \left[-\frac{1}{2}e^{-r^2}\right]_0^{\infty} = \frac{1}{2}$

steps.title: Compute angular integral
steps.content:
$I^2 = \frac{\pi}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2} = \frac{\pi}{4}$

$I = \frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2}$

solution.conclusion: $\int_0^{\infty} e^{-x^2} \, dx = \frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2}$. This is the Gaussian integral.

exercises.statement: Compute the volume of the region bounded by $x^2/a^2 + y^2/b^2 + z^2/c^2 \leq 1$ (an ellipsoid).

steps.title: Change of variables
steps.content:
Let $x = au$, $y = bv$, $z = cw$.

The ellipsoid becomes the unit sphere $u^2 + v^2 + w^2 \leq 1$.

Jacobian: $\frac{\partial(x,y,z)}{\partial(u,v,w)} = abc$.

steps.title: Volume of unit sphere
steps.content: $\text{Vol}(\text{unit sphere}) = \frac{4\pi}{3}$

steps.title: Transform
steps.content: $\text{Vol}(\text{ellipsoid}) = \iiint_{u^2+v^2+w^2 \leq 1} abc \, du\, dv\, dw = abc \cdot \frac{4\pi}{3}$

solution.conclusion: Volume $= \frac{4\pi abc}{3}$. When $a = b = c = r$, this gives $\frac{4\pi r^3}{3}$.

examples.title: Differential Forms and Wedge Product
examples.statement: Define differential forms and the wedge product.

steps.title: 0-forms
steps.content: A 0-form is a smooth function $f: U \to \mathbb{R}$.

steps.title: 1-forms
steps.content:
A 1-form is $\omega = \sum_{i=1}^n f_i \, dx_i$ where $f_i$ are smooth functions.

It acts on vectors: $\omega(v) = \sum f_i v_i$.

steps.title: 2-forms
steps.content:
A 2-form is $\omega = \sum_{i<j} f_{ij} \, dx_i \wedge dx_j$.

In $\mathbb{R}^3$: $\omega = f_{12} \, dx \wedge dy + f_{13} \, dx \wedge dz + f_{23} \, dy \wedge dz$.

steps.title: Wedge product
steps.content:
$dx_i \wedge dx_j = -dx_j \wedge dx_i$ (antisymmetric).

$dx_i \wedge dx_i = 0$.

Example: $(dx + dy) \wedge (dx - dz) = dx \wedge dx - dx \wedge dz + dy \wedge dx - dy \wedge dz$
$= 0 - dx \wedge dz - dx \wedge dy - dy \wedge dz$.

solution.conclusion: Differential forms generalize functions and provide the natural objects for integration.

exercises.statement: Compute the exterior derivative of $\omega = xy \, dx + yz \, dy + zx \, dz$ in $\mathbb{R}^3$.

steps.title: Definition of d
steps.content:
For a 1-form $\omega = \sum f_i \, dx_i$:
$d\omega = \sum df_i \wedge dx_i = \sum_j \frac{\partial f_i}{\partial x_j} dx_j \wedge dx_i$

steps.title: Compute d(xy dx)
steps.content:
$d(xy) = y \, dx + x \, dy$

$d(xy \, dx) = (y \, dx + x \, dy) \wedge dx = y \, dx \wedge dx + x \, dy \wedge dx = -x \, dx \wedge dy$

steps.title: Compute d(yz dy)
steps.content:
$d(yz) = z \, dy + y \, dz$

$d(yz \, dy) = z \, dy \wedge dy + y \, dz \wedge dy = -y \, dy \wedge dz$

steps.title: Compute d(zx dz)
steps.content:
$d(zx) = x \, dz + z \, dx$

$d(zx \, dz) = x \, dz \wedge dz + z \, dx \wedge dz = -z \, dx \wedge dz$

steps.title: Combine
steps.content:
$d\omega = -x \, dx \wedge dy - y \, dy \wedge dz - z \, dx \wedge dz$

Or in standard order: $d\omega = -x \, dx \wedge dy + z \, dz \wedge dx - y \, dy \wedge dz$

solution.conclusion: The exterior derivative of a 1-form is a 2-form. This generalizes the curl in vector calculus.

examples.title: Stokes' Theorem
examples.statement: State the general Stokes' theorem for differential forms.

steps.title: Statement
steps.content:
Let $\Omega$ be a smooth oriented $k$-chain in $\mathbb{R}^n$, and let $\omega$ be a $(k-1)$-form of class $C^1$. Then:

$\int_{\partial\Omega} \omega = \int_{\Omega} d\omega$

steps.title: Special cases
steps.content:
When $k = 1$ (curve): $\int_a^b df = f(b) - f(a)$ (FTC)

When $k = 2$ (surface): $\oint_{\partial S} \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{r} = \iint_S (\nabla \times \mathbf{F}) \cdot d\mathbf{S}$ (Classical Stokes)

When $k = 3$ (solid): $\oiint_{\partial V} \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{S} = \iiint_V (\nabla \cdot \mathbf{F}) \, dV$ (Divergence theorem)

solution.conclusion: The general Stokes' theorem unifies all classical integral theorems of vector calculus.

exercises.statement: Use Stokes' theorem to evaluate $\oint_C y \, dx + z \, dy + x \, dz$ where $C$ is the circle $x^2 + y^2 = 1$, $z = 0$, oriented counterclockwise.

steps.title: Setup
steps.content:
Let $\omega = y \, dx + z \, dy + x \, dz$.

By Stokes: $\oint_C \omega = \iint_S d\omega$ where $S$ is any surface with $\partial S = C$.

steps.title: Compute dÏ‰
steps.content:
$d\omega = dy \wedge dx + dz \wedge dy + dx \wedge dz$
$= -dx \wedge dy - dy \wedge dz + dx \wedge dz$

steps.title: Choose surface
steps.content:
Take $S$ to be the unit disk $x^2 + y^2 \leq 1$, $z = 0$.

On this surface, $dz = 0$, so the only surviving term is $-dx \wedge dy$.

steps.title: Integrate
steps.content: $\iint_S d\omega = \iint_S (-1) \, dx \wedge dy = -\iint_S dx \, dy = -\pi$

solution.conclusion: $\oint_C y \, dx + z \, dy + x \, dz = -\pi$.

exercises.statement: Prove Green's theorem as a special case of Stokes' theorem.

steps.title: Setup
steps.content: Green's theorem: $\oint_C P \, dx + Q \, dy = \iint_D \left(\frac{\partial Q}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial P}{\partial y}\right) dx \, dy$

steps.title: Define 1-form
steps.content: Let $\omega = P \, dx + Q \, dy$ (a 1-form in $\mathbb{R}^2$).

steps.title: Compute exterior derivative
steps.content:
$d\omega = dP \wedge dx + dQ \wedge dy$
$= (P_x \, dx + P_y \, dy) \wedge dx + (Q_x \, dx + Q_y \, dy) \wedge dy$
$= P_y \, dy \wedge dx + Q_x \, dx \wedge dy$
$= (Q_x - P_y) \, dx \wedge dy$

steps.title: Apply Stokes
steps.content:
$\oint_{\partial D} \omega = \iint_D d\omega$

$\oint_C P \, dx + Q \, dy = \iint_D (Q_x - P_y) \, dx \, dy$

solution.conclusion: Green's theorem is exactly Stokes' theorem for 1-forms on 2-chains in $\mathbb{R}^2$.

exercises.statement: Show that $\nabla \times (\nabla f) = 0$ for any $C^2$ function $f$.

steps.title: Compute gradient
steps.content: $\nabla f = (f_x, f_y, f_z)$

steps.title: Compute curl
steps.content:
$\nabla \times (\nabla f) = \begin{vmatrix} \mathbf{i} & \mathbf{j} & \mathbf{k} \\ \partial_x & \partial_y & \partial_z \\ f_x & f_y & f_z \end{vmatrix}$

$= (f_{zy} - f_{yz}, f_{xz} - f_{zx}, f_{yx} - f_{xy})$

steps.title: Apply equality of mixed partials
steps.content:
For $f \in C^2$: $f_{xy} = f_{yx}$, $f_{xz} = f_{zx}$, $f_{yz} = f_{zy}$.

Therefore $\nabla \times (\nabla f) = (0, 0, 0) = \mathbf{0}$.

solution.conclusion: The curl of a gradient is zero. In differential forms: $d(df) = d^2 f = 0$.

exercises.statement: Show that $\nabla \cdot (\nabla \times \mathbf{F}) = 0$ for any $C^2$ vector field $\mathbf{F}$.

steps.title: Let F = (P, Q, R)
steps.content: $\nabla \times \mathbf{F} = (R_y - Q_z, P_z - R_x, Q_x - P_y)$

steps.title: Compute divergence
steps.content:
$\nabla \cdot (\nabla \times \mathbf{F}) = (R_y - Q_z)_x + (P_z - R_x)_y + (Q_x - P_y)_z$

$= R_{yx} - Q_{zx} + P_{zy} - R_{xy} + Q_{xz} - P_{yz}$

steps.title: Apply mixed partials
steps.content:
$= R_{xy} - Q_{xz} + P_{yz} - R_{xy} + Q_{xz} - P_{yz} = 0$

(Using $R_{yx} = R_{xy}$, etc.)

solution.conclusion: The divergence of a curl is zero. In differential forms: $d^2 = 0$.
